pull_request.title: Add XMSS parameter xmss_sha256_h10
pull_request.body:
<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->
# Add XMSS parameter xmss_sha256_h10

This version of XMSS:

1. Original XMSS has signature format: `(sm || m)` (signature concatenates with message). This PR separates `sm` and `m`. Minimal change to internal of XMSS. See: 
a. https://github.com/ducnguyen-sb/xmss-reference/commit/954308800a0ba47357c881838e8ce585a9cd3d97#diff-c79859c458945f7449e50f5ca7e44857716c35763142802cba881cdfd0a61df7
b. https://github.com/ducnguyen-sb/xmss-reference/commit/954308800a0ba47357c881838e8ce585a9cd3d97#diff-2089b4bfa66835b4b7b1d2b4c54c9622288b9149badc7dfd92167fc194f8961a


3. Original XMSS has hash calls like this:

```c
static int core_hash(const xmss_params *params,
                     unsigned char *out,
                     const unsigned char *in, unsigned long long inlen)
{
    unsigned char buf[32];

    if (params->n == 24 && params->func == XMSS_SHA2) {
        OQS_SHA2_sha256(buf, in, inlen);
        memcpy(out, buf, 24);
    }
    else if (params->n == 24 && params->func == XMSS_SHAKE256) {
        OQS_SHA3_shake256(out, 24, in, inlen);
    }   
    else if (params->n == 32 && params->func == XMSS_SHA2) {
        OQS_SHA2_sha256(out, in, inlen);
    }
    else if (params->n == 32 && params->func == XMSS_SHAKE128) {
        OQS_SHA3_shake128(out, 32, in, inlen);
    }
    else if (params->n == 32 && params->func == XMSS_SHAKE256) {
        OQS_SHA3_shake256(out, 32, in, inlen);
    }
    else if (params->n == 64 && params->func == XMSS_SHA2) {
        OQS_SHA2_sha512(out, in, inlen);
    }
    else if (params->n == 64 && params->func == XMSS_SHAKE256) {
        OQS_SHA3_shake256(out, 64, in, inlen);
    }
    else {
        return -1;
    }
    return 0;
}
```
This PR optimizes hash call via define macro at compile time. The goal is to write just enough code to serve the hash call, and avoid branch jump during execution. Example for parameter `xmss_sha256_h10`:

```c
#include <oqs/sha2.h>
#include "hash.h"

int core_hash(const xmss_params *params,
              unsigned char *out,
              const unsigned char *in, unsigned long long inlen)
{
    (void)params;
    OQS_SHA2_sha256(out, in, inlen);
    return 0;
}

```
4. Share code: This PR has plan to share code between parameters using define and namespace. The differences between parameters at compile time is handled by carefully craft `CMakefile.txt`

5. Additional robust check for unsigned int and memory initialization error: 

https://github.com/ducnguyen-sb/xmss-reference/pull/17/files

6. A way to generate NIST-KAT: 

https://github.com/ducnguyen-sb/xmss-reference/pull/16/files#diff-b8143f018bcb227109839d76aa73c408742fa1fd56b6c4013833274583321c4d

All the changes above are propagated to this PR. 



<!-- Does this PR resolve any issue?  If so, please reference it using automatic-closing keywords like "Fixes #123." -->

<!-- Please answer the following questions to help manage version and changes across projects. -->

* [ ] Does this PR change the input/output behaviour of a cryptographic algorithm (i.e., does it change known answer test values)?  (If so, a version bump will be required from *x.y.z* to *x.(y+1).0*.)
* [x] Does this PR change the list of algorithms available -- either adding, removing, or renaming? Does this PR otherwise change an API? (If so, PRs in [oqs-provider](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider), [OQS-OpenSSL](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl), [OQS-BoringSSL](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/boringssl), and [OQS-OpenSSH](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssh) will also need to be ready for review and merge by the time this is merged.)

<!-- Once your pull request is ready for review and passing continuous integration tests, please convert from a draft PR to a normal PR, and request a review from one of the OQS core team members. -->

repo.name: liboqs
repo.description: C library for prototyping and experimenting with quantum-resistant cryptography

3. Original XMSS has hash calls like this:

```c
static int core_hash(const xmss_params *params,
                     unsigned char *out,
                     const unsigned char *in, unsigned long long inlen)
{
    unsigned char buf[32];

    if (params->n == 24 && params->func == XMSS_SHA2) {
        OQS_SHA2_sha256(buf, in, inlen);
        memcpy(out, buf, 24);
    }
    else if (params->n == 24 && params->func == XMSS_SHAKE256) {
        OQS_SHA3_shake256(out, 24, in, inlen);
    }   
    else if (params->n == 32 && params->func == XMSS_SHA2) {
        OQS_SHA2_sha256(out, in, inlen);
    }
    else if (params->n == 32 && params->func == XMSS_SHAKE128) {
        OQS_SHA3_shake128(out, 32, in, inlen);
    }
    else if (params->n == 32 && params->func == XMSS_SHAKE256) {
        OQS_SHA3_shake256(out, 32, in, inlen);
    }
    else if (params->n == 64 && params->func == XMSS_SHA2) {
        OQS_SHA2_sha512(out, in, inlen);
    }
    else if (params->n == 64 && params->func == XMSS_SHAKE256) {
        OQS_SHA3_shake256(out, 64, in, inlen);
    }
    else {
        return -1;
    }
    return 0;
}
```
This PR optimizes hash call via define macro at compile time. The goal is to write just enough code to serve the hash call, and avoid branch jump during execution. Example for parameter `xmss_sha256_h10`:

    return 0;
}

```
4. Share code: This PR has plan to share code between parameters using define and namespace. The differences between parameters at compile time is handled by carefully craft `CMakefile.txt`

5. Additional robust check for unsigned int and memory initialization error: 

https://github.com/ducnguyen-sb/xmss-reference/pull/17/files

6. A way to generate NIST-KAT: 

https://github.com/ducnguyen-sb/xmss-reference/pull/16/files#diff-b8143f018bcb227109839d76aa73c408742fa1fd56b6c4013833274583321c4d

All the changes above are propagated to this PR.

5. Additional robust check for unsigned int and memory initialization error: 

https://github.com/ducnguyen-sb/xmss-reference/pull/17/files

6. A way to generate NIST-KAT: 

https://github.com/ducnguyen-sb/xmss-reference/pull/16/files#diff-b8143f018bcb227109839d76aa73c408742fa1fd56b6c4013833274583321c4d

All the changes above are propagated to this PR.

pull_request.title: Add XMSS parameter xmss_sha256_h10
pull_request.body:
<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->
# Add XMSS parameter xmss_sha256_h10

This version of XMSS:

1. Original XMSS has signature format: `(sm || m)` (signature concatenates with message). This PR separates `sm` and `m`. Minimal change to internal of XMSS. See: 
a. https://github.com/ducnguyen-sb/xmss-reference/commit/954308800a0ba47357c881838e8ce585a9cd3d97#diff-c79859c458945f7449e50f5ca7e44857716c35763142802cba881cdfd0a61df7
b. https://github.com/ducnguyen-sb/xmss-reference/commit/954308800a0ba47357c881838e8ce585a9cd3d97#diff-2089b4bfa66835b4b7b1d2b4c54c9622288b9149badc7dfd92167fc194f8961a


3. Original XMSS has hash calls like this:

```c
static int core_hash(const xmss_params *params,
                     unsigned char *out,
                     const unsigned char *in, unsigned long long inlen)
{
    unsigned char buf[32];

    if (params->n == 24 && params->func == XMSS_SHA2) {
        OQS_SHA2_sha256(buf, in, inlen);
        memcpy(out, buf, 24);
    }
    else if (params->n == 24 && params->func == XMSS_SHAKE256) {
        OQS_SHA3_shake256(out, 24, in, inlen);
    }   
    else if (params->n == 32 && params->func == XMSS_SHA2) {
        OQS_SHA2_sha256(out, in, inlen);
    }
    else if (params->n == 32 && params->func == XMSS_SHAKE128) {
        OQS_SHA3_shake128(out, 32, in, inlen);
    }
    else if (params->n == 32 && params->func == XMSS_SHAKE256) {
        OQS_SHA3_shake256(out, 32, in, inlen);
    }
    else if (params->n == 64 && params->func == XMSS_SHA2) {
        OQS_SHA2_sha512(out, in, inlen);
    }
    else if (params->n == 64 && params->func == XMSS_SHAKE256) {
        OQS_SHA3_shake256(out, 64, in, inlen);
    }
    else {
        return -1;
    }
    return 0;
}
```
This PR optimizes hash call via define macro at compile time. The goal is to write just enough code to serve the hash call, and avoid branch jump during execution. Example for parameter `xmss_sha256_h10`:

```c
#include <oqs/sha2.h>
#include "hash.h"

int core_hash(const xmss_params *params,
              unsigned char *out,
              const unsigned char *in, unsigned long long inlen)
{
    (void)params;
    OQS_SHA2_sha256(out, in, inlen);
    return 0;
}

```
4. Share code: This PR has plan to share code between parameters using define and namespace. The differences between parameters at compile time is handled by carefully craft `CMakefile.txt`

5. Additional robust check for unsigned int and memory initialization error: 

https://github.com/ducnguyen-sb/xmss-reference/pull/17/files

6. A way to generate NIST-KAT: 

https://github.com/ducnguyen-sb/xmss-reference/pull/16/files#diff-b8143f018bcb227109839d76aa73c408742fa1fd56b6c4013833274583321c4d

All the changes above are propagated to this PR. 



<!-- Does this PR resolve any issue?  If so, please reference it using automatic-closing keywords like "Fixes #123." -->

<!-- Please answer the following questions to help manage version and changes across projects. -->

* [ ] Does this PR change the input/output behaviour of a cryptographic algorithm (i.e., does it change known answer test values)?  (If so, a version bump will be required from *x.y.z* to *x.(y+1).0*.)
* [x] Does this PR change the list of algorithms available -- either adding, removing, or renaming? Does this PR otherwise change an API? (If so, PRs in [oqs-provider](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider), [OQS-OpenSSL](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl), [OQS-BoringSSL](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/boringssl), and [OQS-OpenSSH](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssh) will also need to be ready for review and merge by the time this is merged.)

<!-- Once your pull request is ready for review and passing continuous integration tests, please convert from a draft PR to a normal PR, and request a review from one of the OQS core team members. -->

pull_request.title: prepare 0.5.0 release
pull_request.body:
Prepares v0.5.0 release. 

Also adds support for `liboqs_DIR` to skip build of `liboqs` (see https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider/issues/171#issuecomment-1571896664).

Also streamlines scripting to permit smooth integration into openssl "external tests" harness.

repo.name: oqs-provider
repo.description: OpenSSL 3 provider containing post-quantum algorithms
